author: Vijaita Singh
text:
Hamid Akram, Governor of Kabul, was stopped by immigration authorities on Thursday evening at the Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose International Airport in Kolkata, when he landed without a visa.

Mr. Akram arrived in a chartered plane, accompanied by 35 diplomats and officials to witness his country play against Sri Lanka at the Eden Gardens stadium in the ongoing World T20 Cricket championship.

Indian authorities bailed out the Governor by offering him a “temporary landing permit”. The permit was provided on “gratis” basis.

“The Afghanistan government official had a diplomatic passport but there was no visa on it. He was stopped by the immigration authorities. Since he is a diplomat, we extended all cooperation and provided him the temporary landing permit,” a senior government official said.

The temporary landing permit is valid for three days.

“It is unlikely that the official was not aware of the rules. Even diplomatic passport holders require a visa to travel abroad. There were 35 others with him who refused to proceed without him and there was a minor commotion at the airport,” said the official.

The chartered plane from Afghanistan landed at 5 p.m. at the Kolkata airport and the delegates were to watch the cricket match at 7 p.m.

Officials fast-track temporary permit, allow him and his team to watch T20 match at Kolkata
title: When Kabul Governor came without a visa
